document.masterDocTitle: Synopsis of Epipleoneura (Zygoptera, Coenagrionidae, “ Protoneuridae ”), with emphasis on its Brazilian species

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Synopsis of Epipleoneura (Zygoptera, Coenagrionidae, “ Protoneuridae ”), with emphasis on its Brazilian species

bibRefCitation.author: Racenis
bibRefCitation.refString: Racenis, J. (1960) Cuatro nuevas especies del genero Epipleoneura (Odonata: Protoneuridae). Acta Biologica Venezuelica, 3 (2), 25 - 42.

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Epipleoneura machadoi
Rácenis 1960
: 37
–40, figs. 4 a–c (new species, description of male and female, illustration of male S 10 in posterior and lateral view, female prothorax and mesostigmal lamina in dorsal view, type material at MIZA ).
Lencioni 2005
: 178
, figs. 108 a–c (references, type locality, distribution, described stages, reproduction of original illustrations of male S 10 in lateral and posterior view and female prothorax in dorsal view).
Garrison et al. 2010
: 352
, 355, fig. 2346 (included in list of species, illustrations of epiproct in posterior view).
Pessacq et al. 2012
: 4
(included in list of Brazilian Protoneuridae , new record for Mato Grosso State).

.

Diagnosis. Male cercus resembles that of
E. capilliformis
. The cercus (
Fig. 2
) possesses a well-developed triangular inner-basal branch directed posteriorly, unique for this species. The branches of the bifurcate epiproct (
Figs. 2
b–c) are separated at their bases by a triangular swollen structure (TS,
Fig. 2
b) and are fingerlike, with considerable degree of intraspecific variation (see below). The male cercus and epiproct of
E. machadoi
also resemble those of
E. kaxuriana
,
E. ottoi
, and
E. westfalli
, from which they differ by the triangular inner-basal branch of the cercus (
Figs. 2
a, c). For further comments see under related species (
E. kaxuriana
,
E. ottoi
, and
E. westfalli
). The genital ligula (
Fig. 41
) is like that of
E. kaxuriana
,
E. ottoi
, and
E. westfalli
. The female posterior margin of pronotum (
Fig. 62
) is unique in having a small medial projection accompanied by two small rounded lateral lobes, and the anterior margin of pronotum with two rounded lobes at the sides of midline.

Distribution. Central Brazil in Mato Grosso, Minas Gerais, and Espiritu Santo States ( Type locality Buenópolis, Minas Gerais,
17 º 52 ’ 22 ”S
,
44 º 10 ’ 48 ”W
).

Notes.
Epipleoneura machadoi
is well represented in MNRJ , with about
370 specimens
, showing considerable intraspecific variation.
Figures 67
a–f show the different morphological types of the epiproct, from branches parallel to slightly divergent and well separated at their bases to fused along basal half.
Figures 67
b and c show the most common form, agreeing with the original description.
Figures 67
a to 67 e belong to specimens from the same site and date (Baixo Guandu River, route Baisco-Ituituba,
27–30 iv 1970
), from which
174 specimens
were examined.
Figures 67
d and 67 f are atypical, possibly showing extremes of morphological variation. The specimen illustrated in figure 67 d was collected in the same river and similar date as mentioned above (Baixo Guandu river, km 11,
11– 16 v 1970
).

Cercus varies less than epiproct; inner-basal branch may or may not have a very small tooth pointing dorsally, ventral branch in some specimens forms an angle slightly greater than 90 º with dorsal branch, and posterior margin of dorsal branch is straight in lateral view (not slightly convex) in a few specimens. These last characters are useful in the separation of
E. machadoi
from
E. ottoi
.
